data.title: TileMap collision issues
data.body:
When importing a TileMap into a scene, the collision of the tiles may be off by a few units. This can be fixed by manually looking at the exported XML file and changing all of the values to the correct ones.

Of course, it would be easier if the exporter created the correct collider coordinates by itself.

data.title: Project Manager is processing gamepad input
data.body: similar to #813 which was fixed, the Project Manager is processing gamepad input, and while less destructive than the editor itself processing gamepad input, it is still annoying when you might be running a project directly from the Manager, and then buttons are going through and, for example, launching a bunch more copies of the project.

data.title: changed viewport clearing to use the alpha value of the clear color, and...
data.body: ... made the transparent bg option of viewport force a clear color of 0,0,0,0

data.title: Make fullscreen go to the primary monitor under X11
data.body:
This fixes #1408.

Prior to this change, fullscreen would always open on my second monitor (Ubuntu 14.10, dual head, nvidia driver). It _looks_ like `DefaultRootWindow(x11_display)` is returning bad information and the `XGetWindowAttributes()` call should be using the `x11_window` variable like all of the other calls. But I've never done any X11 programming so I don't fully understand what's going on here.

data.title: Add OpenGL state cache to avoid performance penalties
data.body: Since state changes in OpenGL may quickly degrade performance on mobile platforms, maybe it could be added a state cache in the rasterizer to keep track of those changes

data.title: const of base class not accessible
added option to disable automatic clearing of viewport render buffer
Cannot compile android export template
data.body:
scons: **\* [drivers\libdrivers1.android.opt.debug.a] The parameter is incorrect
scons: building terminated because of errors.

how to fix that?
using windows 8.1 x64, latest android sdk & ndk..

compile params: scons platform=android armv6=yes target=release_debug -j 8

data.title: Fullscreen goes to second monitor in Linux
data.body: I have two 1920x1080 monitors. Ubuntu 14.10. Fullscreen almost always goes to the second monitor. The only way I can get fullscreen to go to the primary monitor is if I adjust the y-position of the primary monitor to be lower (y-primary > y-secondary) than the secondary and if the secondary monitor is unrotated.

data.title: "in" operator doesn't match int/float
data.body:
1 in [1.0] => false
1.0 in [1] => false
They are both true in Python (and that is what I expect!).

data.title: Don't prevent exporting to one arch if the other arch's export template is missing
data.body:
I am trying to package Godot for a Linux distribution (Mageia), and there is one aspect that bothers me in the export feature: for the Linux and Windows templates, if you don't have all four export templates (32/64bit, release/debug), you can't export your game, even if you were only planning to use e.g. the 64_release template.

In my example, is the 32_release template really needed to export to 64bit, or is it just an overzealous test that locks down the export feature?

My main concern with this is that I can't package the Godot tools for 32bit systems, since I can't provide 64bit templates on such systems (32bit distros don't have 64bit package repositories). On the other hand, I'd like to package my 64bit Godot with the 64bit Linux export template, and make the 32bit export template optional, for 64bit users that don't enable 32bit repositories on Mageia.

data.title: Fixed issue #1377 about script editor parenthesis matching.
Camelcased script variables will now capitalize in the inspector.
data.body:
Variables like this in GDScript:

export var aNewVariable
export var ANewVariable
export var aNew_variable
export var a_new_variable
etc...

Now, all show up as "A New Variable" in the inspector

data.title: shader from old scene still visible
data.body: In 2D, edit a shader's code.  With the code window still open, open a new scene.  Sometimes (but not always?), the shader window remains visible.  Changes to this code then have no effect.  When the scene with the shader is reloaded, all changes that were made in the out-of-place code window are lost.

data.title: Wrong name for android apk in wiki
data.body:
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/compiling_android

Godot-release-unsigned.apk (first mention) should be Godot-debug-unaligned.apk
Godot-release-unsigned.apk (second mention) should be Godot-release-unaligned.apk

(I think, because there is nothing called unsigned produced).

data.title: Changed the tooltip message for instancing a scene.
data.body:
- Old wording was misleading as it gave the impression that you could select any node from another scene.
- New wording matches the functionality that you instance the entire scene as a single node.

data.title: Implement return value from yield()
data.body:
To create generator functions, we need yield(value) to be implemented. This would act like yield(), but 'value' would be passed back and returned from the resume() call.

This would allow range() to be made into an iterator, rather than creating a potentially huge array.

This would also be a step towards nice features like list/dict comprehension.

data.title: Fix sprintf errors
Tutorial_instancing out of date, can't complete
data.body:
_Instancing, Step by Step
To learn how to do instancing, let's start with downloading a pre-made scene.
Unzip this scene in any place of our preference. Then, add this scene to the project manager using the 'Import' option._

The problem is the 'Import' option is completely different. Instead of the dialog box in the picture, when I choose 'Import' -> '3D Scene', I'm presented with a different dialog with numerous options and a 'source scene' and 'target path'.

No matter what I try I get an unhelpful error - 'Error importing scene.'

data.title: sprintf() doesn't halt on error properly
data.body:
The sprintf code, which is accessed via "string % array" (Which I implemented) doesn't halt the interpreter on errors. When a parsing error occurs, such as if there are too many values in the array, it just prints out the error message nicely, then returns an empty string...

Not at all sure what I did wrong...

data.title: Spatial raycast stops to collide detection on huge complex meshes
data.body:
As the title say: when a complex meshes (like blender auto-generated landscape) is too spatially wide, the raycast of kinematic/rigidbody fail to detect it's collision.
This problem is not effected by the number of vertex/faces.. but only when the spatial scaled size

the small demo provided shows the problem mechanics.

http://tempsend.com/C65749CAB5/C6D1/smalldemo.zip
(press "1" to scale up/down and "2" to reset)

the collider stop working when the landscape mesh is upscaled +x100.... but return working when it grow down x99

== the problem is when a mesh reach the size of (landscape size) \* 100?
it looks like a decimal issue? (99+1... some sort of internal "millennium bug"?)

data.title: Official godot_x11 binaries can't locate libssl.so.1.0.0 on Fedora
data.body:
The error is:

```
./godot_x11-1.0stable.64: error while loading shared libraries: libcrypto.so.1.0.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

After doing _ln -s /usr/lib64/libcrypto.so /usr/lib64/libcrypto.so.1.0.0_ , I get this error:

```
./godot_x11-1.0stable.64: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.0.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

After doing _ln -s /usr/lib64/libssl.so /usr/lib64/libssl.so.1.0.0_ , I get this error:

```
./godot_x11-1.0stable.64: /lib64/libssl.so.1.0.0: version `OPENSSL_1.0.0' not found (required by ./godot_x11-1.0stable.64)
./godot_x11-1.0stable.64: /lib64/libcrypto.so.1.0.0: version `OPENSSL_1.0.0' not found (required by ./godot_x11-1.0stable.64)
```

I'm running a Fedora 21 system (64 bits, of course) with Openssl 1.0.1k installed (stock version from official repository)

data.title: Text editor should allow editing non-script files
data.body: We should be able to edit non-script plain-text files in the built-in text editor, with the debugger and syntax highlighting turned off. This would be useful to keep a TODO or Changelog or README file open in a tab for quick reference, and edits without having to open a different piece of software.
